@teachbk The piece I loved about the OP thread was the follow up after those shares to see what the kid wants be called publicly. They may feel comfortable sharing a particular pronoun w you, but not the rest of the class. Or have it shared w family.

@teachbk I reposted this too. In our *rush* to be inclusive, I think we’ve sometimes missed understanding the lived experience of the actual people we are trying to include. I am so grateful for a similar thread I saw last yr that changed my practice to share if you want to, privately.

2-I love the suggestion in the thread of allowing sts to share their pronouns in ways that aren't public, then circling back to them privately to ascertain how they would like to be called in class. While I do the 1st part, I havent faithfully followed the 2nd-will be doing!

I've referenced my own practice of not expecting sts to share their pronouns explicitly in class but rather to approach them more organically; here is yet another thread that challenges us to understand the lived experience & impact we create when we DO expect them. #langchat https://t.co/ePYxjQGp8Q

with those in my bldg, my district & my association. Thank you's, specific notes highlighting something individual to that person, check ins. I am going slow bc there is always a limit on time BUT we also choose what to prioritize in that time. #langchat #ChooseCommunity

-Nothing compares to what those who see you on the daily teaching say in their reference letters

@klasekastellano @Jahdai7 Ditto. I don’t use the term management either to reference student actions, it doesn’t match w creating a community together. However, I also agree there are parts to teaching that are akin to managing-I have to manage my workload for ex, or I manage logistics in class
Always so touched when someone shares how my resources work well for them, yay @glendadehoyos ! #earlylang #langchat https://t.co/fdEBBGZlVZ

@madamednmichael I love everything you said, super important reminders for us to reflect on & be sure we are considering/examining. This chat also reminded me of how the idea of a calm classroom is interpreted differently across people, no single concept; I hadn’t thought about that!

I loved reading this thread from @madamednmichael with great points to push us in thinking intentionally about what we mean when we say calm classroom. Setting up the space, thinking about your own biases, cultural considerations-great reflection! #langchat #earlylang https://t.co/xjDbSpetZm
@SraWitkowski The positive side of being a singleton!

@madamednmichael 6-if I’m not being triggered myself by sensory issues such as noise level, & at the same time, we need to reflect on when-if that should supersede st needs. As a member of the class community, too, I seek to find that balance so we are all successful #langchat

@madamednmichael 5-I greatly appreciate your point about teacher vs student needs; there was a great article a few weeks ago about this very thing. It is critical we look at our own biases & tolerances for diff actions, noise level, etc -I see a balance as valuable, I am more effective #langchat
@madamednmichael 4- which I suspect is more common at #earlylang level then MS or HS, where these skills have *generally* already been attained. #langchat

@madamednmichael 3-& to further clarify, bodily & emotionally safe refers to when some kiddos do not yet have the skills to maintain their own personal space &/or have not yet developed gross motor skills or body knowledge which then leads to a body not in control & unsafe for others in the space

@madamednmichael 2-what I do hope for is a place where kids feel bodily & emotionally safe, have a break from the truly hectic schedule they experience, even at elementary, & learn regulation strategies, which I see as part of “calm”. #langchat

@madamednmichael As a long time proponent of a calm classrm, I greatly appreciate your comments & perspective! I find I often have to qualify what I say to include I dont mean silent or compliant when I envision a calm space, nor that noisy or boisterous actions are frowned upon. 1-

@EThorntonGHS And then add in no public transport, distance to any given place or service is a haul many cannot not make, reliable internet & connectivity is a joke…and so on. Yup, each community has its unique challenges, no monolith of experience or resources!

@ladylanguage411 Yes! As you trace w your finger, you inhale & then exhale. There does need to be a little coaching as some will trace really fast lol I have them free here french https://t.co/Sk89bIGg25 span https://t.co/2yrEUnBlas :)

A5 #langchat breathing mats at every seat, sound lowering headphones, breaks as needed, stuffies, worry stones & other fidgets, etc. for me the key is not in looking for compliance, but fostering strategies for being in community together where all feel safe & welcome

A5 #langchat I love using relaxation or meditation videos on the screen-they naturally convey a sense of calm which I can then harness w my kiddos. I often them on as they enter to set the mood https://t.co/JOZ3UXnvKp

@SraWitkowski Yes! I think many of us do!! And it doesn’t mean we can’t also have energizing activities & excited voices, just finding a balance! Not all kids thrive in a loud or less structured space #langcgat
@ladylanguage411 I feel like if I have to walk out of the room, I am probably pretty frustrated & need a reset; so yeah, it’s gotten to be no fun for me at that point lol
@Profesora_Anita Yes, the luxury of time!
@SraWilliams3 I’m a sucker for wildlife photos!!
A3 #langchat I also have a Pinterest board w pictures of nature I really love, taking a few minutes to scroll thru them is calming for me
A3 #langchat I do breathing exercises myself; sometimes I have to walk out into the hall & do them. I do feel it models for kids that adults use strategies as well when they are ‘in the yellow zone’
@ladylanguage411 My school started using that phrase this year & I love it! Non judgmental but accurate :)
#langchat https://t.co/Sk89bIFIcx

@ladylanguage411 @alancalderon_20 Agreed! I don’t think Calm has to equate w silence at all. I use relaxation music/sounds a lot

A1 #langchat For me, a Calm classroom allows kids a space where they feel safe, have a respite from the often hectic pace of school & life & fosters strategies for experiencing big feelings. I wrote about this here https://t.co/hRKlgAltM0 #earlylang

@LyndallCave @elhiperfocus Thank you for your perspective! I wonder how many kids are getting that teaching around moving through anger in ways that are not destructive. I would also hesitate to generalize one person’s experience to all people. I def appreciate that it’s works for some!

@elhiperfocus What tipped me off was the increase in breaking crayons-I started to notice kids who were really angry were grabbing & breaking them in bunches. And a kid saying they were told to punch their pillow when they’re angry. #RedFlags
@elhiperfocus Oh yes indeed!!! #psychologicalabuse
RT @elhiperfocus: @MundodePepita https://t.co/4j6x0Ba1qq found one
@elhiperfocus Exactly!!!! And then imagine how hard it is to un-condition the brain to disassociate soothing & violent actions. :(((
2/ how we teach kids to cope w angry & frustrated feelings is so important; sending messages that violence or destruction are coping mechanisms doesn’t seem to make any sense at all.

I find it a disturbing trend that kids (& adults) are being given strategies to calm down from anger & rage that include violence. Punching things, destroying or breaking things may seem like a good strategy...until another person is the one being punched. #domesticviolence 1/

Very excited to be giving this presentation on #ADHD on March 30 (6-7pm EST)! Debunking myths, sharing insights & how I've changed my practice over the yrs to intentionally plan through the lens of kiddos w ADHD. Hope to see you then! @CT_COLT #langchat #earlylang https://t.co/bHUc2KIGXg

2/ so, for ex, bc I have a st w limited hand/finger use, I eliminated using thumbs up/down as a mode of whole class check in. This is a continual process of reflecting on ableist biases & working to design lessons & activities intentionally w an equitable lens #langchat

I also want to add that Ive done a lot of work examining access to participation in my classes through the lens of disability & neurodiversity, planning lessons so that the access is there right from the beginning rather than accommodations after the fact. 1/ #langchat
@alancalderon_20 Yes, activities can feel overwhelming. Breaking them down and having fewer pieces for kids to do at any one time has really helped a lot of my sts.

#langchat 3/ supports success for kids. The thing I continually keep in mind is each kid is unique, meaning even w the same neurodiversity, it may present differently in each kid. So focusing on individual strategies specific to each kid is important for me

R5 #langchat kids can record instead of write if they prefer (using seesaw or iPad camera), & I create a lot of mini videos w cc so kids can watch/rewind/read-whichever input works best for them. Some kids draw their answers instead of speaking or writing. Whatever 2/

R5 In so many ways-all attempts at communicating are celebrated. I currently have a selective mute who communicates with gestures & pointing only. for some of my #adhd kiddos, they do fewer parts of an activity or chunked out for success #langchat
#langchat I love this article from @learningforjustice on the topic of bias and expectations for sts https://t.co/v5NbMAPZgs

R3 Ive been attacking expectations that just reinforce compliance both in my class & throughout my school, pushing back on the traditional “model student” idea, examining the why behind what I ask of sts  #langchat

R3 Self motivation so often has its roots in topics & activities of interest/relevancy for sts. I try to incorporate choice into class as much as possible that provides opportunities for kids to explore, interact, & expand on what they are interested in #langchat
@_ZoeSharpe Yes!! Honoring each kids unique self!
#langchat so I would say that engagement is more the word I would use to describe what I hope for my sts.

R2 I dont grade participation nor do I have generalized expectations since each kid brings w them their own needs, identity, & emotions that I work to take into consideration when thinking about what being engaged is for that kid.  #langchat

R1 For my #earlylang classes participation means being part of our community, which can look/sound/be a lot of diff things. Verbal, non verbal, written or drawn, listening, listening while doodling, etc. Being together.  #langchat

7/ which means I spend time teaching & practicing how we get/choose what we need (& what the purpose of these materials is in the 1st place). This is a long term process, w some friends gaining skills more quickly than others. #langchat #earlylang

6/ I have kids who ask why so & so gets a puzzle & they don't or why so & so has blocks. It is a continual convo-building skills of equity with materials. I will add, I try really hard to have "open access" to materials for focusing... #langchat #earlylang

5/ requires a lot of revisiting over time. We are bombarded w messages relating to equality wo a clear understanding of when that applies & when it doesn't. It is true that in my classes I have to do a lot of work to help my kiddos understand this. #langchat #earlylang

4/: Regular convos about equity & each of us getting what we need to focus on our learning & create a welcoming community for all. I have shared often how I liken this to me needing glasses to read. The diff between equity & equality... #langchat #earlylang

3/ to keep things unexpected, another element that is key for many of our neurodiverse friends, not to mention the rest of us! Not everyone gets the same thing, nor does everyone always have smthng waiting at their seat. Herein lies the real work: #langchat #earlylang

@SraScheetz @Prof_F_Henshaw @welangley @AggieAshley I dont see a need to always give credit when in class, I think it depends on their age, the class, etc. But I also think it’s nice to show appreciation on some level, like ‘I love this ___ that so & so made, let’s check it out!’
@TWSteacher @Prof_F_Henshaw @AggieAshley @welangley te etiqueté en este post precisamente porque sé q eres una gran proponent de dar crédito!
@welangley @Prof_F_Henshaw Honestly, I’m not a huge fan either, but it has been a parking space until I can get my own website up & running.
@Prof_F_Henshaw @welangley I hope I am consistently paying it forward for all the help I’ve rec’d & continue to receive!

@welangley @Prof_F_Henshaw And Bill I want to add, people should be paid for the hard work they put into something. I too give away a lot of stuff, but I also do not feel guilty charging for the seriously huge amount of time I spend researching & illustrating my resources. #ourtimeisworthsomething :)))

@Prof_F_Henshaw @AggieAshley @welangley Lo q hago-cito la fuente si comparto una idea/actividad ajena, un enlace q fue compartido por otra persona (por ej hace unos días @TWSteacher compartió un video q encontró ella después de mucho tiempo buscando, dije ‘gracias por compartir’ y le etiqueté) etc
@Prof_F_Henshaw @welangley It happens freq, but I contend that credit is less often given precisely bc, as a field, we view ideas/resources as common material, rather than ‘belonging’ to someone

@welangley @Prof_F_Henshaw I always liken it to artwork-if you were an artist, most likely you would be less hesitant to charge for your hard work & creativity. What I think often gets in our way is the freq contention in our field that we MUST give things away for free

@welangley @Prof_F_Henshaw Lo q me gustaría ver yo: apreciamos a todo lo q es creado, dado gratis y lo q es ofrecido en venta. Cada recurso representa mucho trabajo, mucha energía, mucho tiempo. Dar crédito es el mínimo de lo q podemos hacer, dándoles respeto a lxs creadores de cada tipo de recurso
@Prof_F_Henshaw @welangley 2-la primera implica q todo existe sin propiedad; creo q esa convicción impide la segunda a veces manifestar. #miopinion #ynoesunsubtweettampoco :))))

@Prof_F_Henshaw @welangley Veo una contradicción inherente en unas dos convicciones sobre recursos/ideas originales q existen en la profesión: 1) tienes q compartir todo lo q haces (gratis) y 2) es necesario dar crédito a los q han hecho recursos/pensando en estas ideas originales. 1-

@jenl987 I have only paid once to present, & honestly I was surprised I had to, I had never run into that before. At the very least, we should have free access to the conference & membership to the organization

6/ #langchat so, to return to my 1st in this thread, reframing the ? What do we do for kids w dyslexia? What do we do for kids w Type 1 ADHD? What do we do for kids w selective mutism? And so on. Much like the term #ownvoices, individuals can get lost in the broad groupings

4/ In terms of physical components, such as those I regularly share in tweets, I am careful to make them avail to everyone-wiggle seats, little notebooks for doodling, etc are beneficial to all & reduce stigma when on offer for the whole class #langchat
3/ which provide entry wo needing “accommodations”. Much like other convos re social justice, using the lens of knowledge to intentionally plan content, instruction, and learning spaces. #langchat

2/ #langchat ultimately, my goal is to go beyond accommodations to creating a space designed through the lens of my students in the room; so, if I have #adhd kiddos, how am I planning w knowledge of who they are (& which type of ADHD, how profound etc) to make lessons

6 ty to Galaxy Community Circle for providing conversation & perspective on how we can teach & incorporate pronouns w little kids

5/My reflaction: going forward, I am seeking not only to continue identity work specifically related to pronouns, but also provide organic opportunities to interact & engage w them in little kid ways, keeping them open ended, fluid & affirming for all. #langchat https://t.co/WDxQH9w8XG

4/New perspective: the concept of going beyond the trinary to make space for all genders, gender fluidity, non static gender identity, etc. Keeping in mind that only showing three pronouns can be limiting or send the message that we must choose only 1 is important to remember. https://t.co/VhUewfdDNE

3/I am giving them space to share when/if they want to. Sometimes pronouns are private; asking a kid in the moment or on paper can create an uncomfortable space. I always tell my sts they can indicate their pronoun or not, even when they are written & available to circle or mark https://t.co/rqOw7maYTX

2/ Reaffirmation: sometimes you need to know you are on the right track, otherwise you can be swamped by demoralizing feelings & it can be tough to move forward. I am grateful that in my practice of not requiring my #earlylang sts to name their pronoun, #langchat https://t.co/kNtjkhPf1C

7/ our sts. Even here in my little town, in any given year, we have 8-10 langs represented in homes, which ties directly into the identities of our kids. Making space for all langs has been an important part of my program from its inception #earlylang #langchat

6/ As an aside, I always appreciate convos around translanguaging & heritage langs in our classes that include langs beyond Spanish-finding ways to bring in ALL the langs represented by our sts & not limiting prof convos to only Spanish is so important to ensure we see ALL

5/ I continue to seek ways to bring the TL (at the proficiency level of my sts) together w "big conversations" to both support the language instruction I am tasked w providing AND give my sts tools & skills to make this world better #earlylang #langchat

4/ Along w that, convos related to social justice provide the opportunity to intentionally plan for a combo of TL & Eng allowing kids to explore & comprehend concepts related to injustice, antiracism, action, etc. #earlylang #langchat

3/ What I also know is, as kids enter w ever more complicated challenges, the need to process w them at deep & regular levels takes precedent over language learning. Supporting an explosive ADHD kid takes intense scaffolding, for ex, that can not be done wholly in the TL

2/ In terms of approaches to teaching LANGUAGE, I do believe that the more TL used, the more effective the approach. I also believe that English(or the common lang of the class) is often be used when we don't know strategies for making the TL comprehensible. #earlylang #langchat

My process for creating a minibook
1 come up w engaging storyline 🤞
2 draw illustrations w pencil on paper
3 trace w black felt tip marker
4 erase pencil
5 scan drawings
6 crop images
7 format images in template
8 add text
9 export to pdf

@CecileLaine Yes, bc those biases feed our inconsistent reactions, even subconsciously. It’s an area me & my team have put a lot of effort into over the past 10-15 years, within our classes & across Specials

@CecileLaine 6/ Lastly I might add being consistent in applying those moments of power when they are needed. Kids are extremely observant & notice arbitrary applications of redirection, class norms, etc. This is a significant imbalance of power that cannot be part of a class

@CecileLaine 5/ Community-I believe very strongly in fostering class community that we all are part of, including the T. Taking part in all activities, instead of standing aside, apologizing when wrong, enthusiastically accepting suggestions from sts, engaging in discussions not lectures etc

@CecileLaine 4/ Guided discovery gives them the opportunity to make their own predictions, observations, & conclusions, wo right or wrong answers (sometimes right-wrong answers hold power over kids in judgmental ways)

@CecileLaine 3/ on the personal space of others. #neurodiverse #adhd 

-Content: great ideas already mentioned (voting, choice, following interests of sts, etc). I will add another which I love-guided discovery, where sts do the exploring of content rather than me telling them what its about

@CecileLaine 2/ For ex, “sitting appropriately”-what does this mean for kids who are unable to control their bodies or conform to certain ways of sitting due to body size or tone. Being able to stand, move about, go for a walk, etc at the discretion of the st gives them autonomy wo infringing

@pamwesely 3/ I reach out to families & kids when they are ready to share to do that in class if they are interested, I regularly connect w kids on a 1:1 basis about heritage, I invite kids to write in whatever lang (outside of English lol) they want in a variety of activities, and so on

5 but it is a hallmark of white culture to beat around the bush, avoid direct statements & making waves,most esp amongst white women, a gender bias @MCanion mentioned. Brené exhorts us to stand up & take the risks bc the outcome is indeed worth it #langchat

3 when we choose to avoid conflict at the expense of our own well being or others, we shld examine our motives. The consequences of speaking our truth are varied & freq involve risk; how &when do we deem speaking up, regardless of consequence, more imprtnt than the risk #langchat

2 #langchat #slowchat aids in continual learning & growth of perspective. It also helps me in the endless process of developing language to talk about these issues, both w adults & w m sts, which sometimes can be hard. Educating myself is ongoing.

#langchat #slowchat A3 I think its really important for us to approach these not as “hot topics” but through the lens of what we are driven to change. Following people & organizations working to facilitate change, regardless of whether they are from the TL community... 1-

3 #langchat #slowchat This becomes even more challenging when you are the *only* space where this celebration / recognition might be occurring. The urge to shout from the roof tops “SEE THESE PEOPLE!” Is hard to resist.

2- #langchat #slowchat Many of my sts dont even know their classmates may speak another lang at home, or celebrate diff holidays, etc. And while I desperately want to celebrate these friends, I have learned over the yrs not to identify them as such until they are ready.

#langchat #slowchat One thing I struggle w is how to navigate the unspoken norm of assimilation while at the same time attempting to raise awareness that there various heritages & identities represented within our school. 1-

2 #langchat #slowchat Intersectionality as a frame has helped greatly-so for ex, in teaching continents to my 1st graders this cycle, I used mini photos of women climate activists from around the world, organically including BIPOC & LGBTQ as a conscious choice

#slowchat #LangChat A2 adding to last evenings few tweets. I really try to approach my planning w the ? Who can I include in this topic/lesson? W the very limited time I w my sts, which feels like a hurdle in itself, I find myself striving to maximize the moment. 1-

@BBRlaPROF Precisely! & this is where taking a yearlong or program long approach to planning can also help, using the continuum to ensure we are including multiple perspectives

2- daily life, local/state/national culture to see variance within that can be eye opening, for all ages. This is especially powerful at #earlylang particularly in rural or less diversely populated areas where kids have fewer opportunities to see/interact w a range of peoples

R4 #slowchat #langchat I think this starts w kids understanding that they themselves have culture. Too often culture is presented or understood as something outside their lives. This is where connections & exploring similarities can be powerful-examining our own traditions 1-

2- #langchat racism or stereotypes from the culture of a particular country, lack of representation/inclusion etc are not entirely absent simply bc its #authres Multiple layers of vetting a resource can be necessary to ensure we are honoring all peoples

R3 #slowchat #langchat This is where a critical lens is super important- #authres is not inherently lacking in bias or stereotype. Being cognizant of avoiding the single narrative when it comes to the target culture is importantly, as is examining resources for gender biases 1-

R1 #slowchat #langchat I also think that we often overlook the importance of what I call “small culture”, that everyday culture that makes up so much of life, & can be integrated organically into class, creating a cultural immersion of sorts.
